712984f-a.text:
11-13 East 42nd Street, north side, between Fifth and Madison
Avenues. 13 East 42nd Street, adjoining the Hotel Manhattan,
will later bo replaced by Schrafft's seven-story building.
About 1915.
Irving Underhill.

712976f-a.text:

712975f-a.title: Manhattan: 42nd Street - Madison Avenue
712975f-a.text:
East 42nd Stroet, north side, east from Madison Avenue, shaow-
ing the Church of tho Poly Trinity and the (1st) Grand Central Depot.
Tho church, erectod in 1873, was founded in 1864 by the younger
Stephen H. Tyng. It has sacrilegiously been referred to as ''Tho
Church of tho Poly Oilcloth.''
TPo Grand Contral Depot shown is the first to be erectod on
this sito and stood from 1871 to 1900.
About 1890
Gift of Urbrock Collection

721318f.title: Manhattan: 42nd Street - Madison Avenue
721318f.text:
42nd Street, north side, west from Kadison Avenue. At
the right is the Hotel Manhattan. This structure was later
converted into an office building. It stands on the site of
the old Draper home. In the center is the Bristol Hotel (with
flaa atop) loceted at the N. W. corner of Fifth Avenue. Sil-
houetted against the Times Bldg is the spire of a Presbyterian
Church that faces Bryant Park. Note the ''El'' station at Sixth
Avenue; the subway kiosks in the foreground and the electrified
street car tracks.
About 1910
Ewing Galloway
NO REPRODUCT0UONS

721322f.title: Manhattan: Madison Avenue - 42nd Street (East)
721322f.text:
Madison Avenue, south from E. 42nd Street, showing prominently
the main office of Cushman and Wakefield Inc.;-occupying since 1927
the second floor of the Carbide and Carbon Building. This structure
bears No. 30 E. 42nd Street and is at the southwest corner.
About 1928
MAY BE REPRODUCED

730174f-a.title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - 5th Avenue.
730174f-a.text:
A general view of the midtown Mamhattan Fifth Avenue zone
above 42nd Street as photographed northward from the 25 story
building at No. 309-13 Madison Avenue that adjoins the S. E.
corner of 42nd Street. At the right margin appears the Char-
les \& Co. Bldg. and the Hotel Biltmore. In the lower left
corner is the rooftop of the Manhattan Hotel. This is shortly
to become the National City Co. Bldg. The excavation in the
foreground is for the Canadian Pacific Bldg. This site was
formerly occupied by St. Bartholmews Church. The spires of
the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas and St. Patricks Cathe-
dral indicate the line of Fifth Avenue.
1919
Gift of E.M.Jenks
James Suydam, photo
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE

721324f.title: Manhattan: Madison Avenue - 42nd Street
721324f.text:
Madison Avenue, north from 42nd Street. Old building on N.E. corner
will be demolished in 1919 to make room for Liggett Drug Building.
Manhattan Hotel, on N.W. corner will be remodelled in 1920-21.
Tower of old St. Bartholomew's Church visible on S.W. corner of
44th Street, will be demolished in 1919-20. About 1921 Charles a
Co's building on S.E. corner of 43rd Street will give place to
Prudence Building. Covered subway entrances will go later.
Picture taken during street car strike of 1916.
Summer 1916.
Irving Underhill, Photographer.
qift of E.M. Jenks.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
